title: Ecolab on terrorism prevention task force; Group to find ways to protect U.S. food supply
full text:
Ecolab Inc. said Wednesday that it has joined a government-funded consortium of universities, food companies and research groups charged with finding ways to protect the country's food supply from terrorist attacks.
     The St. Paul-based company, which makes sanitation products for food and beverage processors, said it will help identify disposal and decontamination procedures in case terrorists use biological or chemical weapons against the U.S. food system.
   "Ecolab was asked to participate in this effort because of our depth of expertise in the area of antimicrobial agents and our knowledge of food industry processes from farm to table," Bruce Cords, Ecolab's vice president of environment, food safety and public health, said in a statement.
     Last month, the U.S. Department of Homeland Security awarded the University of Minnesota a $15 million grant over three years to research ways to detect attacks on the food supply before food reaches consumers, assess the risk of an attack and understand the economic impact of such an attack.
     The new University Center for Post-Harvest Food Protection and Defense - the program created with the money - will coordinate efforts of consortium members, which includes Ecolab, General Mills Inc. of Golden Valley and Hormel Foods Co. of Austin.
     The program "is a top priority for Hormel Foods, said Julie Craven, a company spokeswoman. Food terrorism "is something we have a high awareness of."
     Thomas Lee is at tlee@startribune.com.
